INFOBOX.TITLE: Change infection probability
INFOBOX.BODY: By changing the infection probability, you can simulate the effect of introducing or relaxing preventative measures.
INFOBOX.EXAMPLE_1: "Assume that closing schools reduces the probability of infection by 10%."
INFOBOX.DESCRIPTION_1: To simulate this measure, set the slider to -10% (a reduction of 10%). By setting a start and end date, you can simulate the start date and end date of this measure.
INFOBOX.EXAMPLE_2: "Assume that reopening schools increases the probability of infection by 5%."
INFOBOX.DESCRIPTION_2: To simulate this relaxation, set the slider to +5% (an increase of 5%). By setting a start date, you can simulate the starting date of this relaxation. You can leave the end date blank to simulate the relaxation of implemented measures.

GRAPH.INFOBOX: Note: There is some missing data between 2 March 2020 and 14 April 2020. The missing data has been interpolated. For more details, please refer to the Algorithm page.

ALGORITHM.PRED_BODY:
The algorithm uses the SIR model: every individual has a state which is either "susceptible", "infectious", or "removed". As a first step, the data is pre-processed in order to obtain an SIR model for each province. Based on this, the curing probability and infection probability between two provinces are determined. These values can then be used in combination with the available data to arrive at a prediction.

This type of prediction algorithm is network-based: the prediction is made based on the estimated interaction between provinces. Several studies have recently been conducted that apply this principle, all with promising results.

For details on the algorithm, please refer to the adjacent article.
ALGORITHM.DATA_BODY:
The predictions displayed on the dashboard are based on publicly available data. The National Institute for Public Health and the Environment (Dutch: Rijksinstituut voor Volksgezondheid en Milieu or RIVM) offers various data sources. The Esri data source is the most appropriate for this project.[1] This source includes the number of reports per municipality per day, which can then be added up to arrive at a total amount per province.

Because the prediction algorithm uses number of new infections per day and the data source only has the cumulative number of reports available, the number of new infections is determined by taking the difference between two consecutive days. Some additional pre-processing is required to address missing data and mistakes in the data. An explanation of the pre-processing steps can be found on the Downloads page.

DATA.DESCRIPTION: These tables contain the data used to make the predictions. Please note that the data has been pre-processed and may differ from the official numbers. An explanation of the pre-processing steps can be found on the Downloads page.

ABOUT.TITLE: About us
ABOUT.BODY:
This website is maintained by the Network Architectures and Services (NAS) group of the Delft University of Technology. The NAS group belongs to the Quantum and Computer Engineering Department in the faculty of Electrical Engineering, Mathematics and Computer Science (EEMCS).

NAS educates and conducts research in the broad area of complex networks, ranging from man-made infrastructures such as data communications and energy networks, to biological, brain, social and financial networks. The emphasis lies on understanding network characteristics as well as the processes running on top of the network.

The prediction algorithm used on this website is based on a paper published by members of the NAS group, Network-inference-based prediction of the COVID-19 epidemic outbreak in the Chinese province Hubei. More information about the algorithm can be found on the Algorithm page.

MAINTAIN.TITLE: Website maintainers
MAINTAIN.BODY:
This website has been adapted for the NAS group by two masters students, Brian Chang and Liufei Yang. The website is currently maintained by Brian Chang.

The maintainers of the website would like to thank Prof.dr.ir. Piet Van Mieghem and the other members of the NAS group for providing input and feedback during the development of this website.

ORIGINAL.TITLE: Original creators
ORIGINAL.BODY: The original version of this website was produced by a group of five Computer Science students for their final bachelor project. The client for the project was Dr. Huijuan Wang and their coach was Dr. Claudia Hauff. The NAS group would like to express gratitude to the original creators for allowing us to adapt their work:

ABOUT.TITLE: About the data
ABOUT.BODY: On this page, you can download the data used for prediction on this website. Please note that this data has been pre-processed, so some data can be different from the official numbers reported by the RIVM (Rijksinstituut voor Volksgezondheid en Milieu). An explanation of the pre-processing steps follows.

MUNICIPALITY.TITLE: Cumulative confirmed cases per municipality per day
MUNICIPALITY.BODY:
The RIVM reports the cumulative number of confirmed cases per municipality. However, data is not available for some municipalities between 2 March 2020 and 14 April 2020.

  • If the cumulative number of confirmed cases is missing on 2 March 2020 (the date on which the data begins), it is set to 0 for this day.
  • If the cumulative number of confirmed cases is missing on any other day, it is filled in through linear interpolation and rounded to an integer.

CUMULATIVE.TITLE: Cumulative confirmed cases per province per day
CUMULATIVE.BODY:
The cumulative number of confirmed cases per municipality is summed per province to find the cumulative number of confirmed cases per province per day. However, on some days, the cumulative number of confirmed cases decreases between two days. This is due to previous overreporting which was later corrected.

  • If the cumulative number of confirmed cases for a province on day X is higher than some day in the future, we delete day X for that province.
  • The deleted days are filled in through linear interpolation and rounded to an integer.

NEW.TITLE: New confirmed cases per province per day
NEW.BODY:
The RIVM reports the cumulative number of confirmed cases, so to find the number of new confirmed cases per day, the difference between two days is taken for each province. On 2 March 2020 (the date on which the data begins), the number of new confirmed cases is equal to the cumulative number of confirmed cases on that day.

Between 18 January 2022 and 8 February 2022, the number of positive tests were not passed to the RIVM in a timely manner due to the high number of cases. Starting from 8 February 2022, the RIVM uses the date of the positive test instead of the date on which the test result was reported to the RIVM.[1] This new reporting method results in a massive peak in the number of new confirmed cases on 8 February 2022.

  • To flatten the peak, the number of new confirmed cases for each province on 8 February 2022 is initially set to be the same as 9 February 2022.
  • The remaining number of new confirmed cases are spread uniformly between 18 January 2022 and 8 February 2022.
  • The cumulative confirmed cases per province is recalculated to reflect the adjusted number of new confirmed cases on each day.

INHABITANTS.TITLE: Number of inhabitants per province (as of last noted date)
INHABITANTS.BODY: The last noted date is the last date on which the number of inhabitants of any province has changed. It is possible that the number of inhabitants has not been updated for every province on this day. For provinces which do not have an updated number of inhabitants, the most recent estimate is used instead.
